title: Authors and Citation
text: Paul J. Northrop. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Jennifer Ji. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Northrop PJ, Ji J (2024). gamlssx: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models Location, Scale Shape. R package version 1.0.1, https://github.com/paulnorthrop/gamlssx, https://paulnorthrop.github.io/gamlssx/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gamlssx: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape},   author = {Paul J. Northrop and Jennifer Ji},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.1, https://github.com/paulnorthrop/gamlssx},   url = {https://paulnorthrop.github.io/gamlssx/}, }

what: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape
title: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape
text: main aim gamlssx package enable generalized extreme value (GEV) used response distribution generalized additive model location scale shape (GAMLSS), implemented gamlss R package. gamlss.dist R package offer reversed GEV distribution via RGE family, () usual parameterization GEV distribution (block maxima), (b) RGE, shape parameter restricted particular sign, undesirable sign shape parameter influences strongly extremal behaviour. gamlssx package uses usual parameterization, shape parameter ξ\xi, imposes restriction , observation data, ξ>−1/2\xi > -1/2, necessary usual asymptotic likelihood theory applicable. See Rigby Stasinopoulos (2005) gamlss home page details GAMLSS methodology. See also Gavin Simpson’s blog post Modelling extremes using generalized additive models overview use GAMs modelling extreme values, uses mgcv R package fit similar models. VGAM evgam R packages can also used.

title: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape
text: consider fremantle data include gamlssx package, copy data name ismev R package. data contain 86 annual maximum seas levels recorded Fremantle, Australia 1987-1989. addition year sea level, available value Southern Oscillation Index (SOI). use fitGEV() function provided gamlssx fit model data similar first one fitted, data, Gavin Simpson’s blog post. fitGEV() function calls function gamlss::gamlss(), offers 3 fitting algorithms: RS (Rigby Stasinopoulos), CG (Cole Green) mixed (RS initially followed CG). code , use default RS algorithm. fitGEV() offers 2 scoring methods calculate weights used algorithm. , use default, Fisher’s scoring, based expected Fisher information. code justice functionality gamlss package. See GAMLSS books information.
code: # Load gamlss, for the function pb() library(gamlss) # Load gamlssx library(gamlssx) # Transform Year so that it is centred on 0  fremantle <- transform(fremantle, cYear = Year - median(Year)) # Plot sea level against year and against SOI plot(fremantle$Year, fremantle$SeaLevel, xlab = "year", ylab = "sea level (m)") plot(fremantle$SOI, fremantle$SeaLevel, xlab = "SOI", ylab = "sea level (m)") # Fit a model with P-spline effects of cYear and SOI on location and scale # The default links are identity for location and log for scale mod <- fitGEV(SeaLevel ~ pb(cYear) + pb(SOI),                sigma.formula = ~ pb(cYear) + pb(SOI),                data = fremantle) #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 1: Global Deviance = -112.2422  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 2: Global Deviance = -117.4965  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 3: Global Deviance = -118.3007  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 4: Global Deviance = -118.6081  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 5: Global Deviance = -118.7582  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 6: Global Deviance = -118.8344  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 7: Global Deviance = -118.8731  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 8: Global Deviance = -118.8987  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 9: Global Deviance = -118.9102  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 10: Global Deviance = -118.9188  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 11: Global Deviance = -118.9258  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 12: Global Deviance = -118.9269  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 13: Global Deviance = -118.9351  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 14: Global Deviance = -118.9359 # Summary of model fit summary(mod) #> ****************************************************************** #> Family:  c("GEV", "Generalized Extreme Value")  #>  #> Call:  gamlss::gamlss(formula = SeaLevel ~ pb(cYear) + pb(SOI),   #>     sigma.formula = ~pb(cYear) + pb(SOI), family = GEVfisher(mu.link = "identity",   #>         sigma.link = "log", nu.link = "identity"),   #>     data = fremantle, mu.step = c(1, 1, 1)[1], sigma.step = c(1,   #>     1, 1)[2], nu.step = c(1, 1, 1)[3])  #>  #> Fitting method: RS()  #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Mu link function:  identity #> Mu Coefficients: #>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) 1.5007933  0.0149733 100.231  < 2e-16 *** #> pb(cYear)   0.0019490  0.0004982   3.912 0.000195 *** #> pb(SOI)     0.0680347  0.0174751   3.893 0.000208 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Sigma link function:  log #> Sigma Coefficients: #>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) -2.128696   0.088447 -24.068   <2e-16 *** #> pb(cYear)   -0.004574   0.002614  -1.750   0.0841 .   #> pb(SOI)      0.275258   0.112736   2.442   0.0169 *   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Nu link function:  identity  #> Nu Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    #> (Intercept) -0.25619    0.08582  -2.985  0.00379 ** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> NOTE: Additive smoothing terms exist in the formulas:  #>  i) Std. Error for smoothers are for the linear effect only.  #> ii) Std. Error for the linear terms maybe are not accurate.  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> No. of observations in the fit:  86  #> Degrees of Freedom for the fit:  8.375675 #>       Residual Deg. of Freedom:  77.62432  #>                       at cycle:  14  #>   #> Global Deviance:     -118.9359  #>             AIC:     -102.1846  #>             SBC:     -81.62773  #> ****************************************************************** # Model diagnostic plots plot(mod) #> ****************************************************************** #>        Summary of the Quantile Residuals #>                            mean   =  -0.006109438  #>                        variance   =  1.036755  #>                coef. of skewness  =  0.09394729  #>                coef. of kurtosis  =  2.322565  #> Filliben correlation coefficient  =  0.9951795  #> ****************************************************************** # Plot of the fitted component smooth functions # Note: gamlss::term.plot() does not include uncertainty about the intercept # Location mu term.plot(mod, rug = TRUE, pages = 1) # Scale sigma term.plot(mod, what = "sigma", rug = TRUE, pages = 1)

what: Fit a Generalized Extreme value (GEV) GAMLSS Model — fitGEV
title: Fit a Generalized Extreme value (GEV) GAMLSS Model — fitGEV
text: Fits Generalized Additive Model (GAM) Location, Scale Shape GEV response distribution, using function gamlss::gamlss().

title: Fit a Generalized Extreme value (GEV) GAMLSS Model — fitGEV
code: fitGEV(   formula,   data,   scoring = c("fisher", "quasi"),   mu.link = "identity",   sigma.link = "log",   xi.link = "identity",   stepLength = 1,   stepAttempts = 2,   stepReduce = 2,   steps = FALSE,   ... )

title: Fit a Generalized Extreme value (GEV) GAMLSS Model — fitGEV
text: formula formula object, response left ~ operator, terms, separated \(+\) operators, right.   Nonparametric smoothing terms indicated pb() penalised beta splines, cs smoothing splines, lo loess smooth terms random ra   random terms, e.g. y~cs(x,df=5)+x1+x2*x3.  Additional smoothers can added creating appropriate interface.   Interactions nonparametric smooth terms fully supported, produce errors;   simply produce usual parametric interaction data data frame containing variables occurring formula, e.g. data=aids. missing, variables search list. scoring character scalar. scoring = "fisher" weights used fitting algorithm based expected Fisher information, , Fisher's scoring algorithm used. scoring = "quasi" weights based cross products first derivatives log-likelihood, leading quasi Newton scoring algorithm. mu.link, sigma.link, xi.link Character scalars set respective link functions location (mu), scale (sigma) shape (xi) parameters. latter passed gamlss::gamlss() nu.link. stepLength numeric vector positive values. initial values step lengths mu.step, sigma.step nu.step passed gamlss::gamlss.control() first attempt fit model calling gamlss::gamlss(). stepLength length less 3 stepLength recycled length 3. stepAttempts non-negative integer. first call gamlss::gamlss() throws error make stepAttempts attempts fit model, time dividing 2 values mu.step, sigma.step nu.step supplied gamlss::gamlss.control(). stepAttempts < 1 attempts made. stepReduce number greater 1. factor step lengths stepLength reduced extra attempt fit model. default, stepReduce = 2 means step lengths halved extra attempt. steps logical scalar. Pass steps = TRUE write console current value stepLength call gamlss::gamlss(). ... arguments passed gamlss::gamlss(), particular method, sets fitting algorithm, options RS(), CG() mixed(). default, method = RS() seems work well, method = mixed(). contrast, method = CG() often requires step length reduced convergence achieved. fitGEV() attempts automatically. See stepAttempts. Pass trace = FALSE (gamlss::gamlss.control()) avoid writing console global deviance outer iteration gamlss fitting algorithm.

title: Fit a Generalized Extreme value (GEV) GAMLSS Model — fitGEV
text: Returns gamlss object. See Value section gamlss::gamlss(). class returned object c("gamlssx", "gamlss", "gam", "glm", "lm").

title: Fit a Generalized Extreme value (GEV) GAMLSS Model — fitGEV
text: See gamlss::gamlss() information model fitting algorithm.

title: Fit a Generalized Extreme value (GEV) GAMLSS Model — fitGEV
code: # Load gamlss, for the function pb() library(gamlss) #> Loading required package: splines #> Loading required package: gamlss.data #>  #> Attaching package: 'gamlss.data' #> The following object is masked from 'package:datasets': #>  #>     sleep #> Loading required package: gamlss.dist #> Loading required package: nlme #> Loading required package: parallel #>  **********   GAMLSS Version 5.4-22  **********  #> For more on GAMLSS look at https://www.gamlss.com/ #> Type gamlssNews() to see new features/changes/bug fixes.  ##### Simulated data  set.seed(17012023) n <- 100 x <- stats::runif(n) mu <- 1 + 2 * x sigma <- 1 xi <- 0.25 y <- nieve::rGEV(n = 1, loc = mu, scale = sigma, shape = xi) data <- data.frame(y = as.numeric(y), x = x) plot(x, y)   # Fit model using the default RS method with Fisher's scoring mod <- fitGEV(y ~ gamlss::pb(x), data = data) #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 1: Global Deviance = 323.1515  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 2: Global Deviance = 320.4994  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 3: Global Deviance = 320.1414  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 4: Global Deviance = 320.0911  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 5: Global Deviance = 320.084  #> GAMLSS-RS iteration 6: Global Deviance = 320.0831  # Summary of model fit summary(mod) #> ****************************************************************** #> Family:  c("GEV", "Generalized Extreme Value")  #>  #> Call:   #> gamlss::gamlss(formula = y ~ gamlss::pb(x), family = GEVfisher(mu.link = "identity",   #>     sigma.link = "log", nu.link = "identity"), data = data,   #>     mu.step = c(1, 1, 1)[1], sigma.step = c(1, 1, 1  #>     )[2], nu.step = c(1, 1, 1)[3])  #>  #> Fitting method: RS()  #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Mu link function:  identity #> Mu Coefficients: #>               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)     1.2726     0.1921   6.626 2.00e-09 *** #> gamlss::pb(x)   1.3830     0.3193   4.332 3.63e-05 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Sigma link function:  log #> Sigma Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) -0.08760    0.09058  -0.967    0.336 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Nu link function:  identity  #> Nu Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   #> (Intercept)  0.19264    0.08477   2.272   0.0253 * #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> No. of observations in the fit:  100  #> Degrees of Freedom for the fit:  4 #>       Residual Deg. of Freedom:  96  #>                       at cycle:  6  #>   #> Global Deviance:     320.0831  #>             AIC:     328.0831  #>             SBC:     338.5037  #> ****************************************************************** # Residual diagnostic plots plot(mod, xlab = "x", ylab = "y")  #> ****************************************************************** #> 	      Summary of the Quantile Residuals #>                            mean   =  -0.0005916633  #>                        variance   =  1.009922  #>                coef. of skewness  =  -0.007492234  #>                coef. of kurtosis  =  2.78055  #> Filliben correlation coefficient  =  0.9973717  #> ****************************************************************** # Data plus fitted curve plot(data$x, data$y, xlab = "x", ylab = "y") lines(data$x, fitted(mod))   # Fit model using the mixed method and quasi-Newton scoring # Use trace = FALSE to prevent writing the global deviance to the console mod <- fitGEV(y ~ pb(x), data = data, method = mixed(), scoring = "quasi",               trace = FALSE)  # Fit model using the CG method # The default step length of 1 needs to be reduced to enable convergence # Use steps = TRUE to write the step lengths to the console mod <- fitGEV(y ~ pb(x), data = data, method = CG(), steps = TRUE) #> stepLength = 1 1 1  #> stepLength = 0.5 0.5 0.5  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 1: Global Deviance = 337.4163  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 2: Global Deviance = 322.5637  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 3: Global Deviance = 321.03  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 4: Global Deviance = 320.4416  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 5: Global Deviance = 320.2167  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 6: Global Deviance = 320.1324  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 7: Global Deviance = 320.1011  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 8: Global Deviance = 320.0896  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 9: Global Deviance = 320.0855  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 10: Global Deviance = 320.0839  #> GAMLSS-CG iteration 11: Global Deviance = 320.0834   ##### Fremantle annual maximum sea levels ##### See also the gamlssx package README file  # Transform Year so that it is centred on 0 fremantle <- transform(fremantle, cYear = Year - median(Year))  # Plot sea level against year and against SOI plot(fremantle$Year, fremantle$SeaLevel, xlab = "year", ylab = "sea level (m)")  plot(fremantle$SOI, fremantle$SeaLevel, xlab = "SOI", ylab = "sea level (m)")   # Fit a model with P-spline effects of cYear and SOI on location and scale # The default links are identity for location and log for scale mod <- fitGEV(SeaLevel ~ pb(cYear) + pb(SOI),              sigma.formula = ~ pb(cYear) + pb(SOI),              data = fremantle) #> Error in fitGEV(SeaLevel ~ pb(cYear) + pb(SOI), sigma.formula = ~pb(cYear) +     pb(SOI), data = fremantle): No convergence. An error was thrown from the last call to gamlss()  # Summary of model fit summary(mod) #> ****************************************************************** #> Family:  c("GEV", "Generalized Extreme Value")  #>  #> Call:   #> gamlss::gamlss(formula = y ~ pb(x), family = GEVfisher(mu.link = "identity",   #>     sigma.link = "log", nu.link = "identity"), data = data,   #>     method = CG(), mu.step = c(0.5, 0.5, 0.5)[1], sigma.step = c(0.5,   #>     0.5, 0.5)[2], nu.step = c(0.5, 0.5, 0.5)[3])  #>  #> Fitting method: CG()  #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Mu link function:  identity #> Mu Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)   1.2746     0.1923   6.628 1.99e-09 *** #> pb(x)         1.3801     0.3198   4.315 3.88e-05 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Sigma link function:  log #> Sigma Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) -0.08693    0.09060  -0.959     0.34 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> Nu link function:  identity  #> Nu Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   #> (Intercept)  0.19171    0.08467   2.264   0.0258 * #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> NOTE: Additive smoothing terms exist in the formulas:  #>  i) Std. Error for smoothers are for the linear effect only.  #> ii) Std. Error for the linear terms maybe are not accurate.  #> ------------------------------------------------------------------ #> No. of observations in the fit:  100  #> Degrees of Freedom for the fit:  4.000271 #>       Residual Deg. of Freedom:  95.99973  #>                       at cycle:  11  #>   #> Global Deviance:     320.0834  #>             AIC:     328.0839  #>             SBC:     338.5053  #> ****************************************************************** # Model diagnostic plots plot(mod)  #> ****************************************************************** #> 	      Summary of the Quantile Residuals #>                            mean   =  -0.0006504536  #>                        variance   =  1.009723  #>                coef. of skewness  =  -0.004767227  #>                coef. of kurtosis  =  2.781026  #> Filliben correlation coefficient  =  0.99738  #> ****************************************************************** # Worm plot wp(mod) #> Error in as.environment(DaTa): invalid object for 'as.environment' # Plot of the fitted component smooth functions # Note: gamlss::term.plot() does not include uncertainty about the intercept # Location mu term.plot(mod, rug = TRUE, pages = 1)  # Scale sigma term.plot(mod, what = "sigma", rug = TRUE, pages = 1) #> Error in term.plot(mod, what = "sigma", rug = TRUE, pages = 1): The model for sigma has only the constant fitted

what: Annual Maximum Sea Levels at Fremantle, Western Australia — fremantle
title: Annual Maximum Sea Levels at Fremantle, Western Australia — fremantle
text: copy fremantle dataset ismev package. fremantle data frame 86 rows 3 columns. second column gives 86 annual maximum sea levels recorded Fremantle, Western Australia, within period 1897 1989. first column gives corresponding years. third column gives annual mean values Southern Oscillation Index (SOI), proxy meteorological volatility.

title: Annual Maximum Sea Levels at Fremantle, Western Australia — fremantle
Annual Maximum Sea Levels at Fremantle, Western Australia — fremantle
text: data frame contains following: Year: numeric vector years. SeaLevel: numeric vector annual sea level maxima. SOI: numeric vector annual mean values Southern Oscillation Index.

title: Annual Maximum Sea Levels at Fremantle, Western Australia — fremantle
text: Coles, S. G. (2001) Introduction Statistical Modelling Extreme Values. London: Springer.

what: gamlssx: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape — gamlssx-package
title: gamlssx: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape — gamlssx-package
text: Fits generalized additive models location, scale shape parameters generalized extreme value response distribution. methodology based Rigby Stasinopoulos (2005) implemented using functions gamlss package doi:10.32614/CRAN.package.gamlss .

title: gamlssx: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape — gamlssx-package
text: main function gamlssx fitGEV(), calls function gamlss::gamlss(). See gamlssx package page Github information.

title: gamlssx: Generalized Additive Extreme Value Models for Location, Scale and Shape — gamlssx-package
text: Rigby R.. Stasinopoulos D.M. (2005). Generalized additive models location, scale shape (discussion), Appl. Statist., 54, part 3, pages 507-554. doi:10.1111/j.1467-9876.2005.00510.x

what: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV
title: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV
text: functions GEVfisher() GEVquasi() define generalized extreme value (GEV) family distribution, three parameter distribution, gamlss.dist::gamlss.family() object used GAMLSS fitting using function gamlss::gamlss(). difference GEVfisher() GEVquasi() form scoring method used define weights used fitting algorithm. Fisher's scoring, based expected Fisher information used GEVfisher(), whereas quasi-Newton scoring, based cross products first derivatives log-likelihood, used GEVquasi(). functions dGEV, pGEV, qGEV rGEV define density, distribution function, quantile function random generation specific parameterization generalized extreme value distribution given Details .

title: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV
code: GEVfisher(mu.link = "identity", sigma.link = "log", nu.link = "identity")  GEVquasi(mu.link = "identity", sigma.link = "log", nu.link = "identity")  dGEV(x, mu = 0, sigma = 1, nu = 0, log = FALSE)  pGEV(q, mu = 0, sigma = 1, nu = 0, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  qGEV(p, mu = 0, sigma = 1, nu = 0, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  rGEV(n, mu = 0, sigma = 1, nu = 0)

title: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV
text: mu.link Defines mu.link, "identity" link default mu parameter. sigma.link Defines sigma.link, "log" link default sigma parameter. nu.link Defines nu.link, "identity" link default nu parameter. x, q Vector quantiles. mu, sigma, nu Vectors location, scale shape parameter values. log, log.p Logical. TRUE, probabilities eqn{p} given \(\log(p)\). lower.tail Logical. TRUE (default), probabilities \(P[X \leq x]\), otherwise, \(P[X > x]\). p Vector probabilities. n Number observations. length(n) > 1, length taken number required.

title: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV
text: GEVfisher() GEVquasi() return gamlss.dist::gamlss.family() object can used fit regression model GEV response distribution using gamlss::gamlss() function. dGEV() gives density, pGEV() gives distribution function, qGEV() gives quantile function, rGEV() generates random deviates.

title: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV
text: distribution function GEV distribution parameters loc = \(\mu\), scale = \(\sigma (> 0)\) shape = \(\xi\) (\(= \nu\)) $$F(x) = P(X \leq x) = \exp\left\{ -\left[ 1+\xi\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)   \right]_+^{-1/\xi} \right\},$$ \(x_+ = \max(x, 0)\). \(\xi = 0\) distribution function defined limit \(\xi\) tends zero. support distribution depends \(\xi\): \(x \leq \mu - \sigma / \xi\) \(\xi < 0\); \(x \geq \mu - \sigma / \xi\) \(\xi > 0\); \(x\) unbounded \(\xi = 0\). See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_extreme_value_distribution /Chapter 3 Coles (2001) information. observation data, restriction \(\xi > -1/2\) imposed, necessary usual asymptotic likelihood theory applicable.

title: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV
text: See examples fitGEV().

title: GEV family distribution for fitting a GAMLSS — GEV

title: GEV Distribution Expected Information — gevExpInfo
text: Calculates expected information matrix GEV distribution.

title: GEV Distribution Expected Information — gevExpInfo
code: gev11e(scale, shape)  gev22e(scale, shape, eps = 0.003)  gev33e(shape, eps = 0.003)  gev12e(scale, shape, eps = 0.003)  gev13e(scale, shape, eps = 0.003)  gev23e(scale, shape, eps = 0.003)  gevExpInfo(scale, shape, eps = 0.003)

title: GEV Distribution Expected Information — gevExpInfo
text: scale, shape Numeric vectors. Respective values GEV parameters scale parameter \(\sigma\) shape parameter \(\xi\). gevExpInfo, scale shape must length 1. eps numeric scalar. values \(\xi\) shape lie (-eps, eps) approximation used instead direct calculation. See Details. eps vector first element used.

title: GEV Distribution Expected Information — gevExpInfo
text: gevExpInfo returns 3 3 numeric matrix row column named loc, scale, shape. functions return numeric vector length equal maximum lengths arguments, excluding eps.

title: GEV Distribution Expected Information — gevExpInfo
text: gevExpInfo calculates, single pair values \((\sigma, \xi) = \) (scale, shape), expected information matrix single observation GEV distribution distribution function $$F(x) = P(X \leq x) = \exp\left\{ -\left[ 1+\xi\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)   \right]_+^{-1/\xi} \right\},$$ \(x_+ = \max(x, 0)\). GEV expected information defined \(\xi > -0.5\) depend value \(\mu\). functions vectorized calculate individual contributions expected information matrix. example, gev11e calculates expectation \(i_{\mu\mu}\) negated second derivative GEV log-density respect \(\mu\), , 1 indicates one derivative respect \(\mu\). Similarly, 2 denotes one derivative respect \(\sigma\) 3 one derivative respect \(\xi\), , example, gev23e calculates expectation \(i_{\sigma\xi}\) negated GEV log-density one taking one derivative respect \(\sigma\) one derivative respect \(\xi\). Note \(i_{\xi\xi}\), calculated using gev33e, depends \(\xi\). expectation gev11e can calculated direct way \(\xi > -0.5\). components, direct calculation expectation unstable \(\xi\) close 0. Instead, use quadratic approximation (-eps, eps), Lagrangian interpolation values direct calculation \(\xi = \) -eps, \(0\) eps.
